body:
Comment 7 by **xianrenb**: 
Several points:
1. If people could still argue there may be inconsistent coding styles in codes
generated from "gofmt", then "gofmt" is still not doing a very good job. "gofmt" should
be a tool to stop all the arguments. The whole community would benefit from a good tool.
2. If blank line issue are what you guys commented as a minor details of coding style, I
would like to see the removal of the action done by "gofmt" as described in comment 5.
For instance, code would look ugly if only the "package" and "import" parts are
separated by inserting blank lines while keeping other parts unchanged for codes with no
blank line. Either total control of blank lines or none would be consistent.
3. As "package" and "import" parts would be checked and appended blank lines by the
current "gofmt" if needed, I believe adding blank lines to separate code blocks in a
program is considered to be a good coding style. Most programmers would agree and insert
blank lines in their programs when needed. But what if they miss some of the blank lines
somewhere? Currently, they have to verify their code every time carefully before they
commit their code. Would a tool that could help automating this job being feasible?
4. Code generated by "gofmt" is not what individuals write but what allows others to
read. If you guys really follow the original intention of inventing "gofmt", you should
develop "gofmt" to generate the most readable code. "gofmt" should have nothing to do
with individuals' coding style. That means it may hurt somebody's feelings if it does
not output in the coding style that is same as them, but most go programmers would be
able to read others' code in a consistent and readable style. However, "gofmt" works as
in point 2 or comment 5, and different programmers could use blank lines in different
ways. Current go programs are probably not in a consistent and readable style! "gofmt"
should be improved.
